🎩 to @annaleen for this bonkers #dataviz from Quartz, showing how BAS's "doomsday clock" has moved back and forth since Martyl Langsdorf’s design was unveiled in 1947.

BAS’s decision in 2007 to factor climate disruption into the mix makes perfect sense for obvious big-picture reasons, but less obvious is the ‘inflationary’ effect that decision had on perceived risk. From the day before the decision to the day after, the only thing that changed was how BAS ‘measured’ the threat of annihilation. But, in effect, every estimate prior to 2007 became incommensurate — and, weirdly, everything before 2007 ended up looking like the good old days.

It’s worth noting BAS made that change on the eve of the 2008 financial meltdown, when the scale of losses and bailouts mounted by orders of magnitude that would have seemed beyond comprehension just weeks or even days before. And just as the doomsday clock retroactively recasts the entire Cold War as good times, 2008 made the numbers associated with earlier financial spasms seem measly in comparison (the 1984 Chrysler bailout, for example: $1.5B).

Weirdly enough, WiReD has maintained a lively critical analysis of BAS’s clock for years now, including what for me is the central issue. The closer the clock is moved to midnight, the more likely it is to fuel fatalism rather than activism. Maybe we need a metaclock to measure the BAS clock's accuracy? If so, i hope this unreadable helter-skelter diagram ain’t it.

A Google search for WiReD's stories 2007–today, with the obligatory out-of-scope nonsense Google helpfully adds so they can make more money: https://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=%22doomsday%20clock%22%20site%3Awired.com#ip=1

This doesn’t immediately look like more than a pile of rocks covered in lichens, but it is in fact a “rock compass” on Kökar. Rock compasses can be found in the Finnish archipelago and may have been used in the Baltic from the 15th–16th Cs. to show the local difference between the true north and the magnetic north. But by the 17th C. it was realized that fixed corrections are of little use, since the magnetic pole also moves. #history #navigation
Source: https://julkaisut.metsa.fi/assets/pdf/lp/Asarja/a122.pdf

title: The Value Of Owning More Books Than You’ll Ever Read

last_post.content:
Do you own far more books than you'll ever read?

<raises hand>

Here's a useful way to think about it: All those books are what Nassim Nicholas Taleb calls an "antilibrary"

They are the whitespace around your knowledge

They keep you humble -- sure, you know stuff, but behold all the things you *don't* know!

Or, as I put it ... they're a form of "intellectual orienteering"

My essay: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994

A "friend" link if you're not a Medium subscriber: https://clivethompson.medium.com/the-value-of-owning-more-books-than-youll-ever-read-3d60a6046994?sk=d9575f6411ee9d9a756e2b59ab1e9b2e

title: Bomb Cyclone? Or Just Windy with a Chance of Hyperbole?

last_post.content:
"The widespread use of colorful terms like 'bomb cyclone' and 'atmospheric river' ... devised in many cases by the weather-science community, threatens to spin out of control."

Always ask: who benefits? The newspaper of record, in reporting this story, fails to acknowledge its own role as beneficiary of the spinning pageview counters and ad sales resulting from its use of these terms.

Psychologists! This is the APA position on publishing manuscripts online (as far as I can tell) https://www.apa.org/pubs/journals/resources/internet-posting-guidelines

It says you can publish the manuscript, but have to mark it copyright the APA (so no CC-BY, no permission for reuse). This makes it not compliant with funder requirements (e.g. UKRI)

Does anyone know any more about the position of the APA with respect to rights retention?

The Pequod’s sea wings, beating landward, fall
Headlong and break on our Atlantic wall
Off ’Sconset, where the yawing S-boats splash
The bellbuoy, with ballooning spinnakers,

The blocks"

title: Ransomware Profits Dip as Fewer Victims Pay Extortion

last_post.content:
Good news for people who hate #ransomware: gangs' profits have been falling as fewer victims pay a ransom, leading gangs large and small to embrace more desperate tactics, including shaking down victims for a ransom again and again — which makes victims further less inclined to pay. Ransomware responders say a "subtle shift" by law enforcement to offer rapid support for victims has been making a big difference in aiding/speeding/easing recovery, while also generating valuable intel for the likes of the FBI to help blunt future attacks.
https://www.databreachtoday.com/blogs/ransomware-profits-dip-as-fewer-victims-pay-extortion-p-3358
